replies.text: Your table is missing a key piece of data, analysts usually give 12 month price targets, so how accurate did the analysts price turn out to be 12 months later? Also some websites chart out in a graph both what the analysts average price target was, and where the stocks price went overtime. When you do this for some stocks, like T for example, it shows that analysts consistently call it pretty undervalued, and yet the stock also consistently under performs the market andor loses value. By your logic stocks like T would have been a good buy, even though history shows that you would have lost a lot of money in it. On the flipside meanwhile stocks like NFLX and TSLA would have been called dreadful and highly overvalued investments by analysts at various points, when it was actually the best time to buy those supposedly overpriced stocks.
Every single one of those is a tech company, you shouldnt have your whole portfolio in 1 sector
If youre interested in this style of analysis you might enjoy Tipranks.
Interesting. I kind of want to track this and see if it pans out.
Analysts ratings and price targets are absolutely useless information

Usually stock trading below target for a long period of time is a sign of consistent earning downward adjustment, meaning a stock is failing expectation either slower growth or negative growth QoQ. If the company is good, it will eventually go back on growth track like Chipotle and Eli Lilly or like McDonalds or Nike, it needs some serious stock picking skill and long time observing the industrial trend.
AMD is really interesting. One of the lowest percent to price target but 031 analysts rated it as even a buy.
What did you decide?

I should clarify, this isnt my whole portfolio, just some extra cash I came into. Like I said, Ive been investing for several years now so Ive got a portfolio that is more balanced than just this. This exercise is really just to find out where to put this 5k, and if I can find something better than just a broad market index Also, these are not all tech companies, I feel like less than half of them are.
Im intrigued. Tell me a little bit more about Tip Ranks. What is it? Ive never heard of it
Same
He put intel target at 38

Ill be honest its really not. I came to knowast year that NVDA was priced above 700 pre split but I was scared and only invested in QQQM. It then crossed 1000. I read about analyst ratings about ISRG. I invested a small amount after some research. It has gone 20 since then and has been solid despite tech sell off. I think analyst ratings is helpful to screen companies and not go tits up. I think what is usually lost is that they give a price range and typically most of us dont take risk into account and just invest blindly.
Its a site where they aggregate analyst price targets for a large number of stocks. They keep track of how accurate each analyst is for a specific stock so you get a sense of who you should follow.

Its called momentum, you rode a trade that everyone was on and it kept rising just like when Tesla was hit before and other stocks before they stagnate or decline. Analysts are also chasing the hype since very few had 700 upside target on Nvidia before it tripled they keep adjusting depending on the flowtrend
All analysts literally do is move their price targets as the stock goes up and down. It literally is useless information

Not true. Take a look at stock OTGLY. Its video game company CD Project. It has gone up 40 in last 3 months. Yet I researched and 8 analysts think it is a sell and 4 say it is a buy. I still invested because I follow the company and think there is a significant upside and current analyst opinions are recency bias. So I believe analyst opinions are a piece of information. If you blindly follow then you might get burned but using their opinion as a piece of information to screen stocks is valuable.
If analysts truly had a crystal ball why the hell would they give such valuable information away for free?

Agreed. There are also good and bad analysts. I often read reports even from what I consider good services and shake my head at times when its a field I know a lot about. To reiterate, Its a data point. If all the analysts predict a thing even if its wrong it will affect prices.

... They dont. Analysts get paid. And they are supposed to give honest projections. Its not some scam like you guys believe it is. They research the companies, speak to insiders and try to project where the stock price will be in 12 months. They can be spot on with revenue and earnings projections and still be way off on the stock price. Thats the stock market

No one has crystal ball. Again I find it is useful to screen stocks. To follow their arguments for prices. Regarding other question I agree that it cant be 100 right. But some of the opinions are behind paywall. But you still get to see the consensus buysellhold. Also some banks etc are publicly traded right? So they have to be atleast somewhat open about their investments and cant just make shit up. Again we need to do our own research at the end of the day.

I mean analyst is not a protected job description so there is a range, but yes real analysts are good at analyzing the businesses. That the stock market is highly regarded makes share price harder to gauge.
I just find that 90 of analysts follow momentum. Very few of them go against the crowd. Thus their opinions matter very little

replies.text: If you NEED that money for a down payment then Id personally sell.

it makes sense if you are happy with the gains and want to protect the gains in a HYS. Just be happy with the money and dont worry if it goes up another 20 for example. Its all up to your risk tolerance.

Ask yourself this.. if this stock is down in the timeline where you found a perfect home.. you would be willing to wait longer maybe at least 1 year for it to go back up? If no, then you have the answer. You could try to sell half and keep the rest invested. Then you have 50 risk. Please think about tax when you sell also.. you may need to sell in multiple years if that is to your tax advantage.

Personally, Id do a reverse DCA and sell overtime until you have enough for the down payment or found your desired house. That way if the stock keeps going up youll participate and youll keep trimming off the top. Make sure sure sell lots with the lowest long term gains first

Are you relying on that for all of your downpayment? If so, start selling now over the next several months until you get to an amount youre comfortable with as a minimum downpayment. Then leave some in the market. It doesnt have to be all or nothing.
If youre looking at 2 years or so I would start moving most of it to a HYSAMoney Market Account. You can still put some in the SP 500.

we are in the midle of war fear and BRICS rise, those changes will certainly impact share prices in the short an dlong term. i would suggest to look at the nature of your shares company and ask yourself, when war hist and oil routes are closed will that company get hirt or will soar? in any situation let not forget the first finance rule never put all your eggs in one basket. coz it is risky.

I wouldnt look a gift horse in the mouth. 26 return in the ltm, Id sell and allocate cash for the tax liability. Throw the cash in a HYSA and youll be glad you dont have to scrape up the cash when it comes time to buy. Another thing to consider is the politics. If Harris wins, it wouldnt surprise me of we saw an increase in tax liabilities on Cap gains andor income plus the TCJA is expiring next year.

After doing some research I am of the opinion price will soon stagnate if not falling with this AI overhype. The magnificent 7 mostly attributed to AI overdrive has been flat over 1 month now. It is long term capital gain that you need to spread over several years. I will start unloading ACN for 2024 and repeat in 2025. My purchase cost was 135 so I am unloading some now.

couple of years? no it doesnt In fact, if you have decent money from ACN, look for a brokerage that will let you take out a line of credit against the shares when you are ready to purchase. It will likely be limited to 50 of the value of them, but wont trigger a capital gains tax
I wouldnt sell, or sell and buy voo

If you need it in 12 years I would put in SGOV, bonds, hysa, or unpenalized CDs depending on rates and convenience. 3 years and I would do a broad market etf. Like a vanguard fund for total market. Those are 2 fairly conservative options. Keeping it all in 1 stock is begging to have your housing funds blown up. If you insist on holding ACN, sell everything but your principal. If you paid 3k for the stock, sell everything besides 3k worth.
Depends on the company of course. NVDA cant keep up with demand right now. I think there is some over hype too but I dont discount Nvidia at all.

nah 3 years is too short to still be in the market. Any typical 50 bear market associated with recession would take roughly 2 years to bottom, and probably another 4 years to breakeven. Not that those are common, but theyre not uncommon either. Probably around 15 among all bear markets, and if you count 36 bear markets which takes about almost 5 years to recover, thats about half of bear markets. Down payment money 5 years out should be in HYSA, especially when its beating inflation now. Conservative would be closer to 7 years.

The biggest argument is a high yield savings account HYSA will out pace it in a year. I think thats a bit short sighted because their acting like interest rates will never move lower, but their point still stands, currently you would be better off letting it sit and accumulate interest than bag holding. We dont even have to guess at a timeframe or anything. Just take what you would put in intel and calculate your balance in a high yield savings account over the next 2 years by month. That is literally what you are aiming to beat minimum, otherwise its actually a loss for your risk and effort. If in the next 30 days you sell for a 10 pop, great, but the company literally told everyone expect nothing for a year, and even after that, who boy, just know we are working hard and will update then. The longer you hold, the higher that needs to be just to beat the HYSA. Back to the short sightedness of the HYSA . 1 they probably are not doing that, its just a floor they are using to compare what they are doing with their money ex not giving two craps about a 1 dividend and trying to beat it. Their being smart and not marrying the play, stock or HYSA, and we all should be doing that. If the HYSA is no good, dump it and move to the next channel thats best at that time. The difference between intel and HYSA is you can get out of the HYSA at anytime with 0 loss and invest elsewhere, while Intel may have lost value. They 100 dont make perfect plays, but its hard for them to watch others make dumb plays that cant even track interest rates without saying anything. Bottom line, if you plan to be 100 passive, your picks are probably not best, especially if you refuse to pivot when terrible news shows up at the front page of every search engine. Dont do options. If you dont understand options you can lose a lot of money. If you do understand options you can lose an everloving shitton of money. If you watch this sub a week or two youll see guys posting 50k, 100k, 500k losses. Options were originally intended as a way to hedge your positions, and most hedge funds and serious investors still use them for that purpose. It works something like this Say i bought 10000 shares of nvda a couple years ago. Its gone up huge, lets say i paid 10 a share and theyre worth 100 a share now. I could buy long dated like years puts betting on it going to 50 or less. The puts would be very cheap for me to buy because thats very unlikely to happen but now in case something terrible does happen and nvda does crash my puts will pay off and i wont lose everything. Basically like insurance for stock positions, if that makes any sense.

Some people actually do research and make educated guesses but yea, people in this sub are mostly just gambling. Dont do options to gamble like this. This is not what they were originally intended for.

I cut the cable in 2008 when my cablesatellite bill was above 300month not to mention the cost of the receivers. I couldnt justify 300mo for the volume and percentage of commercials I was forced to watch on live TV. My first streaming device was my Wii console and ultimately moved to Roku. Ive been an A La Carte viewer since and am still paying significantly less monthly than I was in 2008, and, unless I need to watch live News or an urgent Weather broadcast Im happy to watch my favorite shows a day or a month, season or year after the networks broadcast live. While I dont subscribe to Disney, Im a Hulu, Amazon Prime, Netflix, YouTube premium, Pandora premium, Paramount with Showtime Peacock commercial free, Apple TV subscriber. The bottom line is I never run out of commercial free great movies, series, shows, documentaries, music, concerts, and global news to watch at my leisure and schedule in addition, my two kids and grandchild can watch pretty much whatever they love commercial free for significantly less than a commercial dominated satellite or cable broadcast which require a subscription for the better and best content anyway Im not a big sports aficionado, so I dont subscribe to the NFL or MLB streams, but know enough people to watch a game with if I really want to. When you get used to watching what you want without constant commercial interruptions, it becomes very difficult and annoying to watch commercials every few minutes. At least for me.
Thats peace of mind, if nothing else

Inflation is always a historical concern for the wealthy. It reduces investment returns those cozy 5 bonds end up with negative actual return for the year when inflation is at 7 and it drives up costs in the job market. If there is anything they hate, its having to pay people more. Who do you think is behind all the bitching about McDonalds paying people 15 hour? Poor people? The rich hate inflation. For working class, if wage gains keep pace with inflation, it can actually be a long term win. The single biggest purchase the noninvestment class ever makes is a home. With a fixed mortgage, if inflation and wages rise 10, its like getting a permanent 10 discount on your single biggest purchase. Now, wages dont always keep pace with inflation so inflation isnt a cure all for the working class but the Fed are taking care of their masters by making sure inflation is prioritized above jobs or overall economic growth.
